Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module A  
Section 2: Recognizing & Reporting Child Abuse, Neglect, & Maltreatment

The Michigan Child Protection Law (Act 238 of 1975, MCL 722.621-722.638) addresses reporting suspected child abuse in Michigan. If anyone is interested in viewing a full text of this law, they can go to: http://www.legislature.mi.gov/documents/mcl/pdf/mcl-act-238-of-1975.pdf

  • Identifies which Positions are Mandated Reporters

    This law identifies mandated reporters and which individuals are required to report. This list includes doctors, nurses, social workers, and many more. And YES child care providers are mandadted reporters.

  • Mandated Reporters MUST Report

    The law states that mandated reporters MUST make a report to Childrenâ€™s Protective Services if they suspect child abuse or neglect.

  • Anyone Can Report to CPS

    This law also states that ALL other people are allowed to file a CPS report.

  • Legal Requirments

    There are many elements to this law that discuss specific processes and legal requirements for reporting, investigating & responding.

  • Failure to Report

    The law also explains that if a mandated reporter fails to report they are civilly liable for the damages caused by the failure. They also can be found criminally guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by up to 93 days in jail and/or a $500 fine.

  • Immunity Protection

    This law also provides immunity protection. If a report is not substantiated, it is not held against the reporter when they are acting in good faith.

  • Reporter Confidentiality

    The identity of the individual that submitted the report is always kept confidential thanks to this law. Neither the parent nor anyone else is provided with this information.
